content.title: Understanding Leopard Gecko Care
content.content: Leopard geckos are 7-10 inch terrestrial lizards native to the semi-deserts and arid grasslands of Afghanistan, Pakistan, India, and Nepal. Known for their manageable size, simple care requirements, and tolerance toward handling, they make excellent first-time reptiles with proper husbandry.
Leopard geckos (Eublepharis macularius) are small terrestrial lizards with distinctive characteristics that set them apart from other gecko species.

content.text: Physical Characteristics:

items: Size: 7-10 inches total length when fully grown
Body Type: Squat body with pebbled skin texture and short legs
Tail: Plump, segmented tail used for fat storage
Unique Features: Unlike most geckos, they have eyelids and cannot climb smooth walls
Coloration: Wild types are dull yellow with brown or black spots and creamy belly. Captive breeding has produced numerous color morphs and patterns

content.text: Natural Habitat:

items: Geographic Range: Afghanistan, Pakistan, India, and Nepal
Environment: Semi-desert and arid grassland terrain
Landscape Features: Packed earth, rocks, dry grasses, and shrubs
Behavior: Naturally dwell in rock stacks and are skilled climbers despite being terrestrial
Camouflage: Spotted pattern provides concealment among rocks and vegetation

rows: Easy - Ideal for first-time reptile keepers
15-20 years typically (some live longer with excellent care)
Crepuscular (most active at sunset and night)
Terrestrial - wider enclosures preferred over tall
Not recommended for beginners - males must never be housed together

content.content: Leopard geckos are exceptional beginner reptiles due to their manageable size, simple care requirements, docile nature, and 15-20 year lifespan. Their tolerance toward handling and forgiving husbandry needs make them ideal for learning reptile care.
Meeting these core requirements ensures your leopard gecko thrives physically and behaviorally.

rows: Provides adequate space for thermoregulation zone and exercise
Zoo Med T5 HO 5.0 or Arcadia ShadeDweller, UVI 1.0-2.0
Supports vitamin D3 synthesis and natural behavior
Enables proper digestion and metabolic function
Prevents respiratory issues while matching desert habitat
Prevents nutritional deficiencies and dietary boredom

content.content: Cohabitation Warning: Leopard geckos should NOT be housed together as beginners. Males will fight aggressively, and even females can experience stress and competition for resources. Single housing is strongly recommended.
Enrichment stimulates natural behaviors and prevents boredom-related stress. Leopard geckos benefit from varied climbing opportunities, multiple hides, and occasional environmental changes.

content.text: Climbing & Exercise Opportunities:

items: Rock Stacks: Create stable climbing structures using smooth sandstone or slate. Leopard geckos are skilled climbers despite being terrestrial
Cork Bark Rounds: Leaned against walls at angles allow climbing and surface texture variation
Sturdy Branches: Low horizontal branches (2-4 inches off substrate) provide elevated basking and exercise
Multiple Levels: Varying surface heights encourage natural exploration behavior
Textured Surfaces: Mix smooth and rough textures to mimic natural rocky terrain

content.text: Hide & Security Structures:

items: Minimum 3 Hides Required: Warm end hide (90-92F), cool end hide (70-77F), and humid hide (70-80% humidity)
Snug Fit Preference: Hides should be just large enough for the gecko to fit comfortably - tight spaces increase security
Opaque Materials: Non-transparent hides provide better sense of security than clear ones
Multiple Entry Points: Hides with 2 entrances allow escape routes and reduce stress
Natural Materials: Cork bark, slate caves, and textured ceramics are preferred over smooth plastics

content.text: Environmental Complexity:

items: Live Plants (If Bioactive): Sansevieria (snake plants), aloe, and hardy succulents add visual barriers and behavioral enrichment
Substrate Depth Variation: Use 2-4 inches in some areas for digging opportunities
Background Texture: Textured backgrounds or back walls with ledges provide additional climbing surfaces
Décor Rotation: Monthly rearrangement of 1-2 decorations provides novel exploration without excessive stress
Scent Enrichment: Occasionally introduce safe items like cork bark from other enclosures (after quarantine) for olfactory stimulation

content.content: Key Enrichment Principle: Leopard geckos thrive with structural complexity that provides climbing opportunities, multiple secure hides, and environmental variety while maintaining proper temperature and humidity gradients.
Understanding natural leopard gecko behavior helps identify normal activity versus potential welfare issues.

rows: Active at sunset, night, and occasionally dawn (crepuscular)
Daytime constant activity may indicate temperature, stress, or hunger issues
Periodic basking under warm zones for 20-60 minutes after cool-down
Never basking = insufficient heat; constant basking = enclosure too cool overall
Most of day spent in hides, emerges at dusk/night
Refusing to hide OR never emerging indicates extreme stress or illness
Alert to prey movement, stalks insects, quick capture
Ignoring food for 2+ weeks (outside winter cooling) suggests illness
Every 4-8 weeks depending on age and growth rate
Stuck shed (especially on toes/tail tip) indicates humidity problem
Regularly explores structures, climbs to elevated spots
No climbing with adequate structures suggests illness or injury
Plump, full tail indicating fat stores
Thin tail indicates illness, parasites, or inadequate feeding
Occasional chirps or squeaks when startled or during breeding
Constant vocalizations may indicate pain or extreme stress

content.content: Recognizing early signs of welfare problems allows quick intervention before conditions become serious.

rows: Tremors, weak limbs, curved spine, soft jaw
Insufficient UVB or calcium/vitamin D3 supplementation
Provide proper UVB (UVI 1.0-2.0) and use Repashy Calcium Plus LoD or Arcadia EarthPro-A at every feeding
No defecation 7+ days, bloating, lethargy, loss of appetite
Inappropriate substrate (overly large particles, loose sand for juveniles), dehydration, low temps
Use appropriate particle substrate or tile/paper, maintain temps, provide humid hide
Retained shed on toes, tail tip, or eyelids
Insufficient humidity (no humid hide or <70% inside)
Provide humid hide with sphagnum moss kept at 70-80% humidity
Gaping mouth, mucus bubbles, wheezing, loss of appetite
Enclosure too cool, excessive humidity (>50% ambient)
Maintain proper temps (basking 94-97F) and ambient humidity 30-40%
Darkened/blistered skin on belly or toes
Direct contact with unregulated heat sources (heat rocks, cables)
NEVER use heat rocks; use overhead halogen bulbs with thermostatic control
Constant hiding, refusal to eat, tail loss, aggression toward keeper
Inadequate hides, improper temps, excessive handling, cohabitation
Provide 3+ proper hides, correct temps, limit handling to 2-3x/week for 10-15 min
Excessively fat tail, fat deposits in armpits/belly
Feed appropriate portions (2 insects per inch of gecko length), provide climbing enrichment

content.content: Morph-Specific UVB Requirements: Albino and less-pigmented morphs (Blizzard, Leucistic) require LOWER UVB levels (UVI 0.5-0.7 vs. standard 1.0-2.0) to prevent eye damage. Use ShadeDweller or adjust distance of T5 HO 5.0 fixture.
This checklist ensures all critical requirements are met before bringing your leopard gecko home.

rows: Minimum adult size; allows proper temp gradient
Provides basking spot and ambient warmth
Prevents overheating and maintains consistent temps
Zoo Med T5 HO 5.0 (over mesh) OR Arcadia ShadeDweller (under mesh)
Vitamin D3 synthesis and circadian rhythm
Ensures UVB levels in safe range (1.0-2.0 standard, 0.5-0.7 albino)
40% topsoil + 40% play sand + 20% Excavator Clay (DIY mix) OR Lugarti Natural Reptile Bedding
Rock stacks, cork rounds, low branches
At least 3 types: crickets, dubia roaches, black soldier fly larvae
Repashy Calcium Plus LoD OR Arcadia EarthPro-A
Calcium + D3 + vitamins at every feeding
Fresh water available at all times
Paper towels, reptile-safe disinfectant, spare hides
Weekly spot cleaning, monthly deep cleaning

content.content: Investment Note: Quality setup requires $300-500 initial investment for proper equipment. Cutting corners on heating, UVB, or enclosure size compromises welfare and leads to costly vet bills. Purchase correct equipment from the start.

Temperature Verification Critical: ALWAYS measure surface temperatures with infrared temp gun, not ambient air temps. Basking stone/hide surface must be 94-97F, and warm hide interior must be 90-92F for proper thermoregulation.
